div.p: April 22, 2020 Update

p.a: Continuity of Learning and Moving Forward Plan - Updated

div.p: April 15, 2020 Update

During these uncertain times, VCU-ACE is working to provide resources for families. Beginning Thursday, April 16, 2020, from noon-1pm and continuing weekly, VCU-ACE will provide an opportunity for parents to join us for a "Lunch and Learn." An interactive and secure Zoom meeting will address different topics each week. There will be a short presentation with time for a Q&A.
Supporting Positive Behaviors at Home will be the first topic. What causes changes in behaviors? How can you bring structure to this "new normal?"
Zoom information:

p.a: Lunch and Learn Zoom Meeting Link

div.p:
Call in Number: US +1 312 626 6799
Meeting ID: 981 818 226
Password: 032586
April 14, 2020 Update

b.span: Dear Accomack County Public Schools Families,

p.span: We want to thank our ACPS families and stakeholders for their patience and support as we transition into our new normal. Ensuring that all students were provided with an opportunity to receive several meals per week has been a major focus thus far. However, we remain committed to providing ALL students with the best education possible. We realize that we cannot duplicate the instructional practices at home which teachers implement in their classrooms. We further understand that there are major discrepancies in access to technology to include hardware and internet services among our students. During these unprecedented and challenging times, we know that facilitating home instruction might not be a priority for every family, however we need every parent and/or guardian’s collaboration to ensure that our students remain engaged in their academic journey during these challenging times.

With the Governor’s statewide closure of schools for the year, we are moving forward with a Continuity of Learning plan for the Division. Our goal is to provide learning opportunities which will review and enhance content taught before March 13, 2020. Our instructional delivery model will be a blended approach realizing that one size does not fit all. Some teachers will teach through a virtual classroom model while others will use packets to deliver instruction. Parents will be given the opportunity to pick up learning packets at meal pickups or the packets will be mailed or emailed to parents. Teachers will keep the lines of communication opened with parents and students by way of scheduled office hours, emails, or other methods implemented to stay connected. Our Continuity of Learning Plan outlines the procedure we will implement as we continue with the 2019-2020 school year and includes an equitable plan for teaching content not taught as of March 13, 2020 to all students.
This plan is subject to change depending on directives and guidance from the Virginia Department of Education.

b.span: Continuity of Learning Instructional Plan April 14, 2020 Through June 5, 2020

p.span: Teachers will continue to provide students with virtual learning activities as a review of skills taught before March 13, 2020. Teachers are encouraged to use online resources for review and enrichment purposes. Teachers can use teleconference calls with students to review instruction and to assign enrichment activities. Teachers are encouraged to TEAM teach specific content when applicable with grade level colleagues as well as with special education and English Language Learner teachers. Assignments should take under two hours to complete. No assignments will be graded.

Teachers will continue to provide review and enrichment activity packets to parents. Parents can pick up packets at their child’s school during meal pick up, teachers can mail packets home or send information via email. Assignments should take under two hours per day to complete. No assignments will be graded. The principal will schedule times for teachers to come to school to create packets.
Teachers will set up office hours to remain accessible to parents and students regarding assignments. This includes Special Education and English Language Learner Teachers.
Schools will update their website with enrichment activities parents can access at home. The Parent Guide provided by VDOE will also be included on the school website.

br.br: Instructional Plan to Incorporate School Year 2019-2020 Curriculum and Moving Forward into 2020-2021 School Year

p.span: The State Superintendent has given eight waivers to accommodate and give flexibility to all seniors that were on track for graduation as of March 13th. Counselors and Principals have been working hard to review each individual senior to determine if a waiver is needed, Locally Verified Credit is needed, if a senior needs additional assignments to meet the passing grade, and/or if the senior has completed all requirements for a Standard or Advanced Diploma.

On May 5thh, the building principal will call each senior that has met all the requirements to be an official 2020 high school graduate. Any senior that has been identified as not meeting the requirements for gradation will have an individual plan to try to meet those needs.

If a senior has not heard from their building principal or a counselor by May7th, please call the school or email the building principal. Further updates will be given at a later date regarding the process of graduation and diplomas.

It is very important for seniors to continue monitoring their school’s website for updated Awards & Scholarships that are posted. The school counselors are still accepting applications, and it is important that students turn them in to the school or organization by the deadlines.

b.span: AP Courses – Taught by ACPS teachers

p.span: ACPS AP teachers are available for any questions or review a student needs before taking the AP exam. Remedial resources have been emailed to the students to study with for the AP Exam. The grade as of March 13th will be their final grade for the semester, and will be recorded as Pass/Fail.

ACPS has been working collaboratively with Virtual Virginia. As of March 30, 2020 all VV students were given the chose to proceed with VV coursework/AP Exam review or be finished with the course with no penalty. The final grade for the course will be recorded as Pass/Fail.

The College Board is proceeding with the AP Exams by offering the students an At-Home 45-minute test. The test has been modified to accommodate the amount of curriculum taught during the spring session. Please contact your school counselor to ensure you are signed up for the AP exam and have all the necessary capabilities to take the exam.

b.span: The following are the dates for the AP Exams: (Optional)

ACPS has been working collaboratively with the Eastern Shore Community College and our Career Coaches on how to proceed with DE. Instruction is still being delivered to complete the course through Distance Learning for specific classes. The current grade as of March 13, 2020 will be recorded on ACPS transcript as Pass/Fail. However, the current letter grade will be recorded on ESCC’s transcript. ESCC is in the final stages necessary to officially record the courses as being completed on the ESCC transcripts.

On March 31, 2020, the ACPS school board approved for all high school standard credits, Virtual Virginia, and Dual Enrollment courses to have the final grade for the individual courses be recorded as Pass or Fail on the report card/transcript.
On March 31, 2020, the ACPS school board approved all middle and elementary schools (grades K-8) record the final grade for the school year as Pass/Fail.
On March 31, 2020, the ACPS school board approved all classes taken in the semester of Spring 2020 will not be calculated in the GPA or Class Rank.
On March 31, 2020, the ACPS school board approved that the Class Rank for the Class of 2020 will be calculated on the standard credits up until the end of fall semester of 2020.

The state requires 36 mandated hours of face-to-face instruction. The state is not granting a wavier or an exemption. In an effort to provide equitable access to instruction for all students, ACPS will offer direct, face-to-face driver education instruction at a later date. We plan to provide in person instruction in a traditional classroom setting when large gathering restrictions are lifted and our schools are accessed by students and staff. We will give advance notification of the dates and time the driver’s education will resume.

b.span: Drivers Education – Behind the Wheel Instruction

p.span: Due to the state order given by the Governor to practice social distancing, ACPS will be temporarily suspending Drivers Ed. behind the wheel instruction. Once the governor lifts the order the division will notify students when the division will reconvene the instruction.
In accordance with the State Superintendent’s Memo #082-20a;

i.span: “School divisions must award standard credit for high school credit-bearing courses by ensuring that students have completed a majority of required standards, competencies, and objectives, including those that are essential for success in subsequent coursework. This process must be based on revised guidelines provided by the Board of Education (forthcoming) on the alternatives to the 140-clock-hour requirement.”

p.span: We are not required to complete all standards/competencies/objectives, only a majority. We are not required to make up the required seat hours or days, however, we do have to provide further instruction to complete the courses required for graduation.
The following is the plan to complete the individual courses for standard credit:
Summer School Program for all students taking a high school course (grades 8-11) for standard credit. The program would consist of:
· Teacher Workday - July 29th & 30th
· Student Sessions – August 3rd – 6th
August 10th – 13th
· Time of Session – 8am – 1:00pm (grab & go breakfast and lunch included)

b.span: If a student does not participate in the summer program, the student will not be eligible to participate in fall or winter sports because the spring 2020 courses are not officially complete.

p.span: If a student is unable to attend the summer program, then he/she would be required to attend a one-hour fifth block after school for two weeks for each class of the 2020 spring semester. That block would focus on the previous year’s course work that was not taught. Again, this will allow ACPS to be able to award the student a standard credit for the course that is needed for graduation.
All students will be promoted to the next grade level. However, their end of year grade as of March 13th will be recorded on the report card as Pass or Fail.
The following is the plan for continued instruction:

During the 2020-2021 school year the school day will be extended by 15 minutes to incorporate curriculum from the previous school year. Most of the previous year’s curriculum would be front loaded at the beginning of the first nine weeks in order to prepare students for a fall Benchmark. This benchmark will be given for grades 6-8. The data will be used as a baseline to determine significant achievement gaps and growth.
All students will be promoted to the next grade level. However, their final grade end of year grade as of March 13th will be recorded on the report card as Pass or Fail.
The following is recommended to ensure all students are given the opportunity to complete the previous grade level curriculum.

During the 2020-2021 school year the school day will be extended by15 minutes to incorporate curriculum from the previous school year. Most of the previous year’s curriculum would be front loaded at the beginning of the first nine weeks in grades 3-5 to prepare students for a fall Benchmark. The data will be used as a baseline to determine significant achievement gaps and growth.

p.span: No assessments taken from the 2019-2020 assessment year will be used for accountability purposes. The assessment window runs from the summer 2019 administration through the spring 2020 administration. The federal waiver of the 2019-2020 assessments as well as the 2020-2021 accountability and reporting, is being finalized for submission to the United States Department of Education.

p.span: Hotspots are available if students can travel, in the parking lots of Kegotank Elementary, Pungoteague Elementary, Arcadia High, Arcadia Middle and Nandua Middle.

p.span: If parents have home internet service and do not have a computer they are to contact the building principal who will coordinate with Jack Bowden, Technology Coordinator, to arrange for a loaner laptop computer.

div.p: March 30, 2020 Update
Dear ACPS,

We understand how difficult the coming weeks will be as you focus on the health and well-being of your family. Accomack County Public Schools will continue to partner with each of you to provide meals-to-go for students and other helpful resources. I know you have many questions regarding how this evolution will look. The special School Board meeting that was to be held at Accawmacke Elementary School on Tuesday, March 31st at 6:30 pm to discuss recommendations regarding COVID -19 will now be held electronically due to the “stay at home” order issued by Governor Northam at 2 pm on Monday, March 30th. This meeting will be broadcast electronically. I will keep you up to date as decisions are made via the Accomack County Public School website or robocall. Please stay healthy, safe and remember we are in this together.
Sincerely,

W. C. Holland,
Superintendent
Dear ACPS Families:

As most of you are aware, Governor Northam extended the closure of all schools in Virginia for the remainder of the academic year. I know that you have many questions and concerns during this unprecedented time. I assure you that I am working with my team to get answers and to provide information in the coming days. The Virginia Department of Education will be providing guidance on the continuity of instruction, grades, and the graduation requirements for Seniors. SOL assessments will not be administered during the 2019-2020 school term.

Your child(ren) may utilize the resources posted on the division website for continuity of learning. In addition, food services will continue to serve meals at the designated locations until further notice.

As always, I will communicate new information via robocall or through the division website. I ask for your patience and understanding as we work through the logistics of this closure. Please stay home, stay safe, and remember that we are in this together.
Sincerely,

W. C. Holland
Division Superintendent
March 23, 2020 Update
School Year Closure -

Governor Northam has ordered all K-12 schools closed for the remainder of the school year in response to the continued spread of the Corona virus. Our division will continue to serve meals to the designated sites until further notice. Please stay home and stay healthy.
March 19, 2020 Update

Accomack County Public Schools is committed to providing enrichment and engaging learning experiences for students during a district closing. The Instructional Department has been given permission from Chesapeake Public Schools to adapt and/or use the Emergency Learning Plans developed by their school division. These Emergency Learning Plans are available for priority content areas to ensure students remain engaged with course content during the extended school closure.

These plans provide a variety of “at home” learning experiences for students to apply prior learning. We encourage students to work on these activities at a pace that works best for your family. The tasks will not be graded or used for grades.
Paper copies of Emergency Learning Plans will be available for pick-up upon request from the school office staff. These requests will be filled and available for pick-up on the next weekday.
Link Below:
March 17, 2020 Update

Our School Board has taken the precautionary measure of canceling the meeting scheduled for March 17th at 6:30 p.m. due to health and safety concerns relating to COVID-19. Thank you for your patience and understanding as we consider the rapidly changing circumstances. As always, the safety and well-being of our students and staff is our top priority.

The Accomack County School District began to offer free breakfast and lunch to all school-age children starting yesterday, March 16th. Breakfasts and lunches will be offered daily from Monday through Thursday from 5:30 pm – 6:30 pm.

Distribution sites include Chincoteague Elementary School, Arcadia High School, Kegotank Elementary School, Metompkin Elementary School, Tangier Combined School, Accawmacke Elementary School, Pungoteague Elementary School and Nandua Middle School.

However, all students may pick up a meal from any of the locations listed. Meals will be served in a drive-up style at the entrance of the cafeteria at each of the designated feeding sites. Children must be present and meals must be consumed off-site.
March 16, 2020 Update

Beginning Monday, March 16, the Accomack County School District will offer a free breakfast and lunch to all school-age children (Ages 18 and under). Breakfasts and lunches will be offered daily from Monday-Thursday beginning on Monday,March 16th, from 5:30 pm -6:30 pm.

Distribution sites include Chincoteague Elementary School, Arcadia High School, Kegotank Elementary School, Metompkin Elementary School, Accawmacke Elementary School, Pungoteague Elementary School, and Nandua Middle School. However, all students may pick up a meal from any of the locations listed. Meals will be served in a drive-up style at the entrance outside of the cafeteria at each of the designated feeding sites. Children must be present and meals must be consumed off-site.

Members of the public who are interested in participating in the School Board Meeting scheduled for March 17th at 6:30 pm are encouraged to do so remotely by listening to the audio available on the division website. This decision is in accordance with CDC guidelines for large events and mass gatherings.
March 13, 2020 Update

By order of Governor Northam, all Accomack County Public Schools will be closed for students and staff from Monday, March 16th through Friday, March 27th. All 12 month employees will report on time until further notice. School facilities will be closed to the public during this time. Classes are set to resume on Monday, March 30th.

p.span: March 12, 2020
Dear ACPS Families, Faculty, and Staff,

The health and safety of our students and staff remains our top priority. Currently, there are no confirmed cases of COVID-19 on the Eastern Shore of Virginia. However, the school division continues to work closely with the Accomack County Health Department, as well as other local, regional and state partners, to prepare for the possibility that the virus could make its way into our community. As the public health concern evolves in Virginia and throughout the nation, we must make difficult decisions. Without exception, we base our decisions upon what we believe is in the best interest of all students and staff and we take this responsibility very seriously. As a result, please note the following updates…

As a proactive measure to protect the health and well-being of our students, faculty, and staff, all school and school-division supported trips (field trips, athletic trips, etc.) outside of Virginia are cancelled through April 13. This includes staff travel to meetings, conferences, etc. Within Virginia, trips will be evaluated on a case by case basis.

We strongly urge families and staff to carefully review and adhere to travel warnings and guidance issued by the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) which may change frequently. If you are traveling to a country with a Level 3 Travel Health Notice, CDC guidance states: “Travelers should stay home for 14 days after returning to the United States and practice social distancing.”

There are no plans to close schools at this time. Any decision to close schools will be made in direct consultation with the Accomack County Health Department. We are currently evaluating all possible options to ensure continuity of instruction if a closure is deemed necessary.

Accomack County Public Schools is taking steps to minimize the spread of COVID-19, as well as other viruses. We have instituted more robust cleaning protocols. We are also taking extra steps to sanitize our school buses. Our division is also encouraging students and staff to pay extra attention in taking normal, everyday preventative measures of such as washing hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, and covering one’s mouth or nose with a tissue when coughing or sneezing. It is imperative that students stay home when sick.
As always, we value our partnership with you as we work together to ensure the safety of our students and staff. Thank you for your cooperation and support.
Sincerely,

W. C. Holland,
Superintendent

div.p: Accomack County Public Schools does not discriminate on the basis of race, color, national origin, sex, disability, or age in its programs and activities.
